understanding.label: A student should understand (Conceptual Understanding)
items: The importance of knowing which reference guide the teacher wants them to use.
They need to refer to the latest edition of the assigned reference guide.
Different schools, departments, and career fields use different reference guides.
The importance of communicating clearly.
The importance of citing sources and giving credit when using sources.

skills.label: A student should be able to do (Evidence of Knowledge)
items: Use the correct reference guide dictated by their course of study or assignment.
Access reference guides online.
Apply the rules for usage dictated by the reference guide to their own writing.
Apply this knowledge in more complex texts than those for Grades 9-10.

anchor_standard.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

knowledge.label: A student should know (Prerequisite Knowledge)
items: To use hyphens when writing compound numbers-for example, twenty-two.
How to hyphenate spelled out fractions.
What the parts of speech are so that they can determine if two words are working together as one word.
Prefixes so they can determine if a prefix and its root word needs to be hyphenated.
Coordinating adjectives are two adjectives of equal value that modify the same noun.

understanding.label: A student should understand (Conceptual Understanding)
items: Compound verbs or verbs with two words can be written as one word or hyphenated. Students need to look words up in the dictionary to be sure of the correct spelling.
To hyphenate two or more adjectives when they come before a noun and act as a single idea.
When compound adverbs are used before a verb (and do not end in -ly), the adverbs are hyphenated. When the adverbs are after the verb, they are not hyphenated.
Hyphens are NOT used to separate coordinating adjectives.
To hyphenate prefixes before proper nouns.
NOT to hyphenate a prefix and root word if the prefix and root word end and begin with different vowels. However, if the prefix and suffix begin and

skills.label: A student should be able to do (Evidence of Knowledge)
items: Use hyphens correctly in writing and any other form of written communications.
Refer to a reputable usage guide or dictionary for the correct spelling of a word when in doubt.
Apply this knowledge in more complex texts than those for Grades 9-10.

Good word choice enhances writing and makes reading more enjoyable.
Contractions are not used in formal writing.

Sentence parts-subjects, verbs, direct objects, predicate adjectives, indirect objects.
Sentence types-simple, compound, complex, compound-complex.

understanding.label: A student should understand (Conceptual Understanding)
items: Writers vary the combination of words in their writing to achieve a purpose. For example, the use of short choppy sentences, though not normally desired, could be used for the effect of showing urgency.
Speakers use syntax to convey a purpose.
Continue to understand how language functions and how to apply the rules of language to their writing, reading, and speaking.

Different sentence patterns and use that knowledge to determine the part of speech of the unknown word.
Words have multiple meanings.

anchor_standard.description: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grades 12-12 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

knowledge.label: A student should know (Prerequisite Knowledge)
items: Dictionaries (print and digital) are used to find word meanings, parts of speech, and pronunciations.
Glossaries are located in the back of texts and are used to define words based on the context of the text.
Students know parts of speech - i.e., noun, pronoun, verb, adjective, adverb, conjunctions, prepositions, interjections.
Thesauruses (print and digital) are used to find synonyms and antonyms.
Synonyms are words that have the same or closely the same meaning.
Antonyms are words that have opposite meanings.
Etymology means the study of word origins and how words have changed over time.

understanding.label: A student should understand (Conceptual Understanding)
items: Words have different meanings based on the context in which they are used.
Dictionaries, glossaries, and thesauruses will give the root word and often give alternative forms of a word to use for different parts of speech.
Words have prefixes and suffixes that can change the meaning and/or part of speech of a word.
Dictionaries, glossaries, and thesauruses are arranged alphabetically.
Words meanings change over time and should consult a reference guide for the correct and current usage.
To be college and career ready, it is important to know not only a wide range of words but how to use reference guides to assure their proper usage.

skills.label: A student should be able to do (Evidence of Knowledge)
items: Use print and digital dictionaries.
Use print and digital glossaries.
Use print and digital thesauruses.
Determine which meaning best fits with the context of the word when words have multiple meanings.
Look up a word's part of speech and be able to use it appropriately in a sentence.
Locate a word's pronunciation guide and pronounce it correctly.
Use a reference guide to trace the origin of a word and how it has changed over time.
Apply this knowledge in more complex texts than those for Grades 9-10.

anchor_standard.description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

knowledge.label: A student should know (Prerequisite Knowledge)
items: Hyperboles are exaggerations writers and speakers use to emphasize a point.
A paradox is a statement that seems contradictory but on further study has truth to it.
Idioms are expressions that do not mean what they literally say.
Figurative language such as metaphors, similes, euphemisms, and oxymorons can be used as figures of speech.
Nuances are slight differences in meaning and that word phrases have different nuances based on their context.

understanding.label: A student should understand (Conceptual Understanding)
items: Writers use figures of speech to achieve a specific effect.
Writers use metaphors and similes as figures of speech to make comparisons.
Writers use hyperboles as figures of speech to emphasize a point.
Writers use euphemisms to soften a point.
Writers use oxymorons to show a juxtaposition of words or ideas or to show a paradoxical event. Writers use oxymorons to make readers think and take notice of what is being described.
Idioms are used in everyday life and are not meant to be literal.
To be college and career ready, they need to be able to read higher level texts, which include sophisticated figurative language.

skills.label: A student should be able to do (Evidence of Knowledge)
items: Recognize a figure of speech and explain its effect on the piece of writing.
Distinguish between overused figures of speech and original figures of speech.
Evaluate the use of a figure of speech in a piece of writing and evaluate whether the figure of speech achieves the author's purpose.
Enhance writing by correctly using original figures of speech to help achieve a purpose in writing.
Apply this knowledge in more complex texts than those for Grades 9-10.

standard.description: Analyze nuances in the meaning of words with similar denotations. anchor_standard.description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

knowledge.label: A student should know (Prerequisite Knowledge)
items: Nuances are slight differences in meaning, tone, or feeling.
Denotation means the dictionary definition of a word.
Words have more than one meaning.
Connotation is the feeling or emotion that is associated with a word.
Words can have similar denotations but different connotations-i.e., eager and anxious.

understanding.label: A student should understand (Conceptual Understanding)
items: Nuances in language add a rich complexity to language, helping writers not only be more specific but also to convey more emotions and meanings in their writing.
Good writers use less traditional means or connotations of words to help achieve their purpose and add variety to language.

skills.label: A student should be able to do (Evidence of Knowledge)
items: Use context clues to determine the detonation and connotation of a word as it is used in its context.
Determine the difference between two (or more) words with similar denotations by the context in which the words are used.
Justify the author's word choice based on the purpose of the writing.
Choose words for writing that help convey purpose and meaning.
Apply this knowledge in more complex texts than those for Grades 9-10.
